elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
SCENE 1: EXT. PARADE GROUND ON THE PLANET SONTAR
(FX: A MILITARY PARADE PASSING BY. THOUSANDS OF TRAMPING
SONTARAN BOOTS IN TIME WITH...
(MUSIC: SLOW, MARTIAL MARCHING THEME, LIKE A COMMUNIST ANTHEM.
DIRGE-LIKE AND UNMELODIC, VIZ ‘HARRY & PAUL’ TITLES)
Sontar! Sontar! We live for Sontar!/
Sontaran troopers are bred for war! Sontar! Sontar! We march for Sontar!/
The might of Sontar is why we march! Sontar! Sontar! We fight for Sontar!/
The glory of Sontar is why we fight! Sontar! Sontar! We die for Sontar!/
The death of our enemies is why we live!
(FX: AND BACK TO THE START. REPEAT ENDLESSLY AS WE CROSS TO —A PODIUM OVERLOOKING THE PARADE)
(SALUTING) Fleet Marshal Stabb, sir! Presenting Field-Major Thurr, sir, as instructed!
Good, good. (TO MEZZ) Stand easy, Sergeant! (TO THURR) You too, Thurr.
As you command, Fleet Marshal. (TOADYING) It is a signal honour to be invited to watch over the passing-out of the Academy —
(INTERRUPTING) No, no, can’t hear you. Louder! Louder!
(LOUDER) I was saying, your eminence, it is an honour to attend such a magnificent muster of Sontaran [clonelings —]
(IGNORING HIM) Eardrums got blown out at the battle of Jerrick- Zero. Ten billion megatons of nuclear cannon-fire — can you imagine that, Thurr?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 4
(A FEEBLE ATTEMPT AT HUMOUR) Why, that would have made these clonelings sound like a bunch of bawling females, sir!
They are females, Field-Major.
What?
It is said that an extra chromosome got into the mix at the breeding plant.
Er — what I meant to say, your eminence, is — bawling Rutan females, Fleet Marshal, sir!
It’s of no concern, I’m sending them to certain death in the Doghead Nebula. (BEAT; SIGH) Permission to laugh, Field-Major.
(STRANGLED LAUGH) Ha ha. Ha ha ha ha.
That is very good, Fleet Marshal, sir —
I was not speaking to you, Sergeant! (BEAT) Now, Thurr. The reason I have recalled you from the Gloom Moons of Aldebaran...
Fleet Marshal, local resistance proved far greater than our strategists anticipated —
Yes, yes, yes, I’ve had them destroyed.
(CONFUSED) The Gloom Moons, sir?
Your strategists, Field-Major.
BEAT
Ha! Ha ha ha ha ha —
(SOTTO) That was not humour, sir.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 5
. Ah.
What does the planet Samur mean to you, Field-Major?
(NOT A CLUE) The planet.. Samur, you said? I, er —
At the furthest reaches of the Madeleine Cluster?
Don’t help him, Sergeant!
Madeleine Cluster, oh yes.

The planet Samur marks the point of our great Empire’s furthest incursion into Rutan space, twenty years ago. Ever since the conquest of Samur, the Empire has concentrated its resources... further back in the Cluster.
(ASIDE) Considerably further back, in fact.
I... understand.
I have a special mission for you, Field-Major. I want you to travel to Samur, immediately —
What, through Rutan space?
Immediately! (TO MEZZ) Sergeant, the canister.
Here, sir. —
This canister is currently sealed. It many only be opened when you have landed on Samur.
But — what does it contain?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 6
Your orders, Field-Major. Orders that must be obeyed to the letter! Now — your ship is ready and waiting. I have personally selected six other Sontaran warriors to accompany you to Samur
Five, in fact, Fleet Marshal —
. and you, Sergeant Mezz. Makes six.
San?l?
Don’t thank me, Sergeant. Ten years you’ve served as my personal adjutant. It’s time you saw some action.
Will it be a dangerous mission, sir?
Highly dangerous! But I know how much the Sergeant relishes the chance to die for the glory of Sontar! Don’t you, Sergeant?
The glory of Sontar. Yes, sir.
Well, then — escort the Field-Major to his ship! Dismissed!
TO THURR) Follow me, sir. (HE AND THURR EXIT
(GRUNTS TO SELF — THEN, SINGING TUNELESSLY ALONG WITH MARCHING ANTHEM) Sontar! Sontar! We die for Sontar!/
The death of our enemies is why we live...
FX: FADE
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 7
SCENE 2: EXT. MOSSY PRECINCT ON SAMUR
FX: TARDIS MATERIALISES. BEAT. DOOR OPENS
FX: NB — ALL CHARACTERS IN BARE FEET

(STEPPING OUT) .. as I explained, Tegan, shoes, boots, slippers and footwear of all kinds are strictly forbidden within the precincts of the Citadel — (BREAKING OFF, SURPRISED BY SURROUNDINGS) ... Ah.
(FOLLOWING) So — what? They don’t want to ruin the carpet?
That’s not carpet, Tegan.
(CURIOUS) No. No, it’s not.
(FX: CLOSING TARDIS DOOR BEHIND HIM) I detect from the tone of your voice that this place is not as you remember it?
(UNCONVINCED BY OWN ARGUMENT) Ah, Turlough. I suppose we might have landed in a part of the Citadel I’ve not seen before.
The Citadel stretches the length of the planet, you said. There must be a lot of it.
(STEPPING FORWARD) Well, what is it, if it isn’t carpet?
Yes, I shouldn’t step on that if I were you. —
FX: SOFT SQUELCHING UNDERFOOT
Too late.
(SLIGHTLY OFF) It’s soft. Kind of... springy.
It’s moss. Purple moss.
Some sort of lichen, certainly.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 8
(SLIGHTLY OFF) But it stretches as far as the eye can see!
Doctor, you’re concerned.
The Citadel of Samur has its own complex ecosystem. A symbiosis between the buildings and those who dwell within them.
And its inhabitants would never have allowed it to become overgrown?
No, they wouldn’t.
Well, I see no ‘inhabitants’.
(RETURNING) No people at all. (BEAT) Know what this means?
Astound us.
We can wear shoes.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 9
SCENE 3: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
(FX: FADE UP. CONTROL ROOM AMBIENCE. DOORS OPENING FROM THE INSIDE)
FX: NB — ALL CHARACTERS IN BARE FEET
(ENTERING) .. I’m sorry, but if I must go tramping around a planet-wide mould, no way am I doing it in bare feet!
(FOLLOWING) It isn’t mould, Tegan.
Moss, mould, fungus, whatever — I do not want it between my toes!
(JUST BEHIND) I’11 fetch the shoes, shall I?
Thank you, Turlough. That would be helpful, yes.
Wait a minute. Where’s Nyssa?
This moss has excited her curiosity. I think she wandered off.
That woman needs to get a life. Turlough, you’d better stop her from going too far.
Me?
Like I said, I’m not stepping foot outside that door without at least a pair of slingbacks!
FX: SLIGHTLY OFF, DOCTOR PRESSING BUTTONS ON CONSOLE
(EXITING) Fine. Fine..!
(STUDYING CONSOLE READINGS) You know, this really is most peculiar.
What is?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 10
The date. It’s only thirty years, local time, since I was last here on Samur. For the Citadel to have fallen into such a state of disrepair in less than thirty years...
Yeah, it looks like no-one’s been here for centuries.
Like I say, most peculiar.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 11
SCENE 4: EXT. MOSSY PRECINCT ON SAMUR
FX: QUICK FADE UP. NB: SOFT SQUELCHING UNDERFOOT THROUGHOUT
(PADDING OVER MOSS, CALLING OUT) Nyssa? Nyssa!
(OFF) Over here, Turlough!
(FX: FOLLOW HIM AS HE WALKS OVER) Nyssa. Tegan sent me to stop you from wandering off. I see she was right to.
Yes, well — I’m not the helpless young girl she thinks I am. Not any more.
Nonetheless, I suggest we stick together.
Don’t worry, I’ll look after you. (IGNORING HIM) Now — courtyard to the east, or courtyard to the west?
Can’t we at least fetch our shoes?
The others can bring them. (DETERMINED) East, I’d say. (WALKS OFF )
(TO SELF) .. No. Evidently. (CALLING OFF) Well, wait for me. —
(FX: EXITS. A BEAT, THEN CROSS TO TARDIS. DOOR CLOSED. TEGAN AND DOCTOR NOW IN SHOES)
Well, where’d they go?
I’m not sure. (CALLING OUT) Nyssa? Nyssa!
She can’t have gone far.
Still, we ought to stick together.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 12
She’ll be fine. She’s not the precious young thing you think she is. Not any more.
I suppose Turlough’s with her.
So she can look after him. (BEAT) What is it with this Citadel of yours?
I don’t follow.
You were so keen to come here. Like you had some sort of agenda?

Well, it’s a retreat. A chance to recharge one’s batteries, in a relaxed but nonetheless stimulating environment. People from across all of the Middle Galaxies used to come to Samur in search of — well, in search of whatever it was they came for. Sanctuary. Solace. Peace of mind.
So what was it? A kibbutz? Some sort of giant hippy commune?
Not exactly, but you’re in the general area.
Yeah, you’d have fitted right in. (GENTLY) I am alright, you know. After the Mara, I mean.
Good. (CHANGING SUBJECT) Now — courtyard to the east, or courtyard to the west?
(PERSISTING) I don’t need a rest cure, Doctor. I don’t need to hug a tree, or sit around a campfire singing ‘Kumbayah’. What I need is to go somewhere, anywhere, that isn’t... dull.
Quite. West, I think. (WALKS OFF)
(CALLING AFTER) I’1ll leave the others their shoes, shall I? (TO SELF) Unbelievable. (WALKS)
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 13
SCENE 5: EXT. COURTYARD EAST
FX: QUICK FADE UP. SOFT SQUELCHING UNDERFOOT
(WALKING) This isn’t one courtyard. It’s a field of courtyards! (TO STOP) Nyssa. We should go back. Nyssa!
(STOPPING) These must have been sculptures, before the moss got to them.
That, or statues. Are you coming?
I should like to see what’s underneath. Do you have a pen- knife?
Why would I have a pen-knife?
You’re a boy, I thought you’d have a pen-knife.
You’re a girl, don’t you have a — I don’t know, a nail file?
(EFFORT, DIGGING INTO MOSS ROUND STATUE) I’1l just have to take it off with my fingers. (BEAT) But it’s very, very — tenacious...
FX: RIPPING, SQUELCHING) There, that’s got it. (BEAT
Turlough? Turlough!
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Over here. What do you make of this?
(FX: FOLLOW HER, WALKING OVER) What is it?
(FX: RATTLING METAL FLAGPOLE) A flagpole, I think. (FX: FLAPPING CANVAS BANNERS) Two ensigns, but they’re faded.
Still, it’s the only thing here that’s not been touched by the moss.
(DRILY) That’s why I remarked upon it.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 14
On the mooring, where you’re standing. I think it’s a plaque.
(FX: STEPPING DOWN FROM MOORING) A what?
A plaque. See? (READING) “In the martial year seventy-five thousand and nine, this planet, its moons and satellites were hereby claimed for the greater glory of —” (BREAKS OFF)
The greater glory of what? What’s it say? Nyssa!
“.. the greater glory of the Sontaran Empire.”
“Sontaran”? What’s “Sontaran”?
FX: CUT TO:
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 15
SCENE 6: INT. THURR’S SHIP
(FX: SHIP IN FLIGHT. ALL SONTARAN TECH IS CLUNKY-, CHUNKY- SOUNDING, SO WE HEAR UNOILED, INELEGANT SWITCHES AND LEVERS; DISCORDANT FARTS FROM CONTROL PANELS, NOT DELICATE BLEEPS)
FX: ELECTRONIC DOOR FROM FLIGHT DECK GRINDS OPEN
(SALUTING) Ah, Field-Major! The platoon await your instructions.

(STEPPING THROUGH DOOR) Good, Sergeant. (STOPPED) Now — pay attention, troops. According to Pilot Bekk on the flight deck, we have now exited warpspace and will shortly be entering orbit about our objective: the planet Samur.
(SHARPLY, WITH RECOGNITION) Samur?!?
Samur, did you say?
Yes — Samur, Trooper... er...
(ASIDE) Jorr, sir.
. Trooper Jorr. Why, does the name Samur mean anything to you?
No, no, sir. It just sounds like a dismal hole.
That is true.
Well, Trooper Jorr — the planet Samur marks the point of our great Empire’s furthest incursion into Rutan space, twenty years ago.
Field-Major! Field-Major! Do you mean, we are in Rutan space right now?
As a matter of fact, we are, Trooper...?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 16
(ASIDE) .. Vend, sir. Passed out of the Academy only recently. Very keen.
Good, good. (TO VEND) Yes, Trooper Vend, we are in Rutan space right now —
VEND/NOLD/JORR:
GRUNTS OF DISQUIET, BUT NOT ALARM
Permission to speak, Field-Major, sir!
Permission granted, Corporal...?
Corporal Clun, Field-Major! Thirty-five years in the Sontaran service, with the scars to prove it!
That is highly commendable, Corporal. Did you have a question?
My question is, Field-Major — if we are in Rutan space, why are we going to Samur when we could be blasting Rutan scum to plasma?
VEND/NOLD/JORR:
GRUNTS OF AGREEMENT
A good question, Corporal, and one I cannot answer before we make planetfall. (FX: TAPS CANISTER AT HIS SIDE) Sealed orders, you understand.
But what if we meet any Rutan scum on the way? Can we blast them to plasma then?

Well, in the unlikely event that we should run into a Rutan patrol in orbit about Samur, then Pilot Bekk will indeed blast them to plasma. (FX: A FAINT FARTING, OFF, AS AN ALARM SIGNAL BEGINS TO THROB BEHIND THURR. IT CONTINUES, INSISTENTLY,
) Now, any further questions? You, with your hand up.
GARGLING: “ALARM, SIR!”
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 17
No, didn’t catch that, Trooper...?
(ASIDE) Nold, sir.
. Trooper Nold. What’s the matter, Trooper? Lost your tongue?
GARGLING: “YES, SIR!”
What’s that?
GARGLING: “I SAID, YES, SIR!”
He means “Yes, sir.” He lost his tongue. Bit it clean through in a podcrash, some years ago.
One moment, I know how Nold speaks. (TO NOLD) Say it again, Trooper.
GARGLING: “ASK HIM, HAS HE NOTICED...?”
Well, what’s he say?
He says, have you noticed...
GARGLING: “”.. THE ATTACK PROXIMITY INDICATOR...”
. the attack proximity indicator...
GARGLING: “IS FLASHING?”
. is flashing!
What?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL)
Page 18
Behind you, sir. The attack proximity indicator appears to be
flashing.
We are under attack?
(FX: MASSIVE ELECTRICAL SOUND, LIKE A THUNDERCRACK,
ON AND REVERBERATING AROUND THE HULL)
THURR/MEZZ/CLUN/JORR/VEND/NOLD:
ALARM, SHAKEN
Sergeant! Status?
(DRY) We appear to have run into
Samur.
That dismal hole!
(FX: A SECOND THUNDERCRACK. MORE
(EXCITED) We’re under attack, by
Do not panic, boy! Do not panic!
a Rutan patrol in orbit
REVERBERATION )
Sontar! Under attack!
(URGENT) We are under
attack! Action stations! We are under attack!
around
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 19
SCENE 7: EXT. COURTYARD EAST
As I recall, the Sontarans were the sworn enemies of the Rutans. An amoeboid species. The Doctor and I met them on Earth, in the Middle [Ages —]
Never mind the Rutans, Nyssa — what about these Sontarans?
A race of troll-like warmongers, apparently. I’ve not actually met one, mind you. But if they’re half as bad as the Rutans...
I said, never mind your Rutans! Not if we need to be watching our backs for trolls...
I see no other evidence of military occupation. But the Doctor will want to see this banner, nonetheless. I suggest we take it back to the TARDIS.
At last!
Here, hold this moss sample while I — (SHE CAN’T GET THE MOSS SAMPLE OFF HER HAND) .. Oh. That’s strange.
What is?
The moss. It seems to have — (EFFORT, TRYING TO FREE MOSS FROM HER HAND) .. stuck to my palm.
Here, let me try to get it off. — (TUGS AT MOSS)
FX: SMALL, ANGRY-SOUNDING SHLOOP
(SMALL YELP. A PINPRICK OF PAIN) Ow!
Sorry. It seems to be some kind of natural adhesive —
It’s more than superglue, Turlough. I think... (BRIEF EFFORT) .. I think it’s rooted.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 20
SCENE 8: EXT. COURTYARD WEST
(FX: QUICK FADE UP. SOFT SQUELCHING UNDERFOOT GIVES WAY TO FOOTSTEPS ON BRITTLE STONE)
(WALKING) This isn’t just one courtyard. It’s a field of courtyards! (TO STOP) Doctor. We should go back. Doctor!
(STOPPED) Yes. Yes, I think you’re probably right. (BEAT) You know, there’s something strange about this moss.
Yes. It’s purple. The same purple it was back where we left the TARDIS. The same purple that’s giving me eye strain.
The colouring’s the same, I agree — but the moss itself is much less dense here.
So? Look — I’m going back, before we get ourselves lost.
One moment, Tegan, if you would. (TO SELF) I wonder... What happens if I... hup! (JUMPS HEAVILY ON THE SPOT)
FX: A DULL CRUNK BENEATH HIS FEET
Interesting. Hup! (JUMPS AGAIN) (NB: NO CRUNK THIS TIME)
What are the star jumps in aid of?

Ah. Well, I noticed that the purple colouring has extended into the stone floor itself, even where the moss isn’t — see? And I wondered if the integrity of the stone itself might have been affected. Hence the impact test.
Well, everything’s fine. Now can we please go and find the others?
Yes, I think that’s probably wise — (TURNS TO LEAVE)
FX: A LOUD CRUNK FROM BENEATH THEM
Did you hear that? It came from beneath our feet!
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 21
Yes. (BEAT) Well, it’s probably nothing. —
(FX: BANG ON CUE — MORE CRUNKS, TO THE LEFT AND THE RIGHT. CRACKING AS THE STONE FLOOR DISINTEGRATES AROUND THEM)
You and your ‘impact test’! The floor’s giving way!!!
Brave heart, Tegan. It’s only a craaaaa-[ck]! (FALLS INTO CRACK)
Doctor!!!
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 22
SCENE 9: INT. THURR’S SHIP
(FX: TWO MORE THUNDERCRACKS IN CLOSE SUCCESSION. JUDDERING, SPARKS. FARTING ALARMS )
Another hit! And another!
We are doomed!
No, no! Our shields can easily absorb this Rutan weaponry. And once their batteries are exhausted — then, then we will turn and blast them to plasma! —
FX: SUDDENLY, ALARMS CUT OFF
BEAT SILENCE
It has all gone quiet.
Like I said, their batteries are exhausted. Now — now I shall instruct Pilot Bekk to strike back, without mercy! (TURNS, BUT...) Strange.
The door to the flight deck is not functional!
(FX: BANGING REPEATEDLY ON BULKHEAD WITH FIST) Pilot Bekk! Activate the flight deck door at once! (FX: BREAKS OFF) Why can he not hear me?
That will be because he’s dead, most likely.

Silence, Trooper Jorr! (FX: BANGS ON DOOR AGAIN; AROUND HERE, THE SHIP BEGINS TO ACCELERATE, A WHINE FROM OUTSIDE INCREASING QUICKLY IN INTENSITY AS THE SHIP BEGINS FALLING THROUGH THE ATMOSPHERE OF SAMUR) Pilot! Pilot, open this door!
Like the doors are dead. The alarms are dead. Face it, the whole ship is dead!
I said silence! If the ship was dead, it would be plummetting helplessly through the atmosphere of Samur —
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 23
(INTERRUPTS, GARGLING: “PLUMMETTING HELPLESSLY IS WHAT [WE’RE DOING, SIR!”])
(ROARS) I — said — silence!!!
(BEAT SILENCE. IN WHICH THE WHINING FROM OUTSIDE BECOMES OBVIOUS)
Permission to speak, Field-Major!
Permission granted, Corporal.
Trooper Nold says, plummetting helplessly through the atmosphere of Samur is what we are doing, sir!
(TO THURR) Regret to inform you — Trooper Nold is correct.
We are Sontaran soldiers, Sergeant! We do not plummet helplessly!
Then I recommend the use of gravity spheres.
Gravity spheres, good. (VERY LOUD, OVER HOWLING FROM OUTSIDE) Abandon ship! I order you all to abandon ship!!!
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 24
SCENE 10: EXT. COURTYARD WEST
(EFFORT, PULLING DOCTOR OUT OF CRACK IN FLOOR) Come on, Doc — put some backbone into it!
(STRUGGLING ON LIP OF CRACK) I have plenty of backbone, Tegan. It’s just that I’m trying very hard not to plummet helplessly to my death in the act of applying it...
FX: CRUMBLING STONEWORK
Yeah, down the crevasse you created! (CATCHES BREATH) Alright, one more heave. —
DOCTOR/TEGAN: (BOTH STRAINING) Heeeeave! !!
FX: DOCTOR STUMBLES OUT OF CREVASSE, SCATTERING LOOSE STONE
Thank you.
So, Einstein — what do we do now, given there’s a ten-foot crevasse keeping us from the TARDIS?
(GETTING UP, DUSTING SELF DOWN) Like I said, the Citadel’s vast. I’m sure there’ll be another way round, even if we have to traverse the breadth of the planet. (BEAT) Joke.
Well, I’m not laughing.
No. (CHANGING SUBJECT) Interesting, though. This moss.
Not that again.

Yes, that again. Where it touches the floor directly, like here, the ground is perfectly solid. But where the ground is merely dyed, the stonework’s brittle, like it’s been weakened on the molecular level.
Meaning — what?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 25
I have a theory.
I’m not going to like this, am I?
Not a lot, no. What if the dyed, brittle ground indicates an area that the moss has already passed over...?
You mean — it’s eating the floor!?!
Eating anything it roots itself to, I suspect. What’s more, it’s moving.
This gets better and better.
At an incredibly slow rate, of course. But given time, I’ve no doubt it could consume the entire planet. Such an organism could never have arisen naturally.
Oh, great. Attack of the Purple Astroturf!
. of the Alien Purple Astroturf, yes. (PATTING POCKETS) One moment. Somewhere here I should have...
What are you looking for? Weedkiller?
(FINDING PEN-KNIFE) Ah! (FLOURISHING IT) Pen-knife.
Figures. You always had a bit of the Boy Scout about you.
Well, I promise to do my best. Now — (FX: APPLYING PEN-KNIFE TO A PATCH OF MOSS; SOFT SQUELCHES) — let’s see if we can’t cut a
sample free. Taking care not to touch the underside, of course...
Why?
. There, that’s got it. And I don’t want to touch the underside [because —]
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 26
Uurgh, it’s moving!
Well, its roots are. Looking to anchor themselves into whatever they can find, and suck it dry atomically.
You wouldn’t want that on your skin.
Yes, I imagine it’d destabilise human flesh rather sooner than it does stone. The question I have is:
FX: QUICK CUT TO:
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 27
SCENE 11: EXT. COURTYARD EAST
(STOPPING, SLIGHTLY BREATHLESS) What happened here, I wonder?
Never mind that now, Nyssa. We have to get back to the Doctor. The TARDIS. (BEAT) How’s the hand?
See for yourself.
(DOUBLE-TAKE) But it’s gone!
Not exactly. It’s moved further up my arm — see?
It’s moving?!?
Slowly, yes.
You mean, it’s alive?
Obviously. The question is not, “Is it moving?” The question is, “Why is it moving?”
And “Where to?”, I suppose.
There’s a biotronic agitator in the TARDIS. That’d purge the infection, I’m sure.
Best we get a move on, then.
I feel weak. I could use some support, Turlough.
Well, I can see it’s worrying, but I’m sure it’1ll all be alright —
Not that sort of support! Your arm? (BEAT; SIGHS) You won’t catch it, I don’t think it’s done with me yet.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 28
I wish I had your certainty. (BEAT) Alright, then. Put your arm around my [waist] — (FX: INTERRUPTED BY SONIC BOOM FROM SKY ABOVE )
What was that?!?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 29
SCENE 12: EXT. COURTYARD WEST
(EXCITED) Up in the sky, Doctor! Look!
Good heavens.
A shooting star! .. It’s breaking up!
Given the perfect sphericality of the parent object, and its descent trajectory... unlikely.
Well, what is it, then? .. Don’t say a spaceship.
A spaceship. Sorry. And that’s not debris in its wake. Escape pods, maybe? Spherical, too. (MORE TO SELF) And terribly familiar. —
The big ship’s coming down. It’s gonna [hit!]
(FX: DROWNED OUT BY DEEP RUMBLING IMPACT FROM TWO MILES AWAY.
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 30
SCENE 13: EXT. COURTYARD EAST
FX: DYING ECHOES OF IMPACT
(SHOULDERING NYSSA) Whatever that was, it wasn’t far away.
(SHOULDERED) Two point five to three kilometres, I think.
(SHOULDERING NYSSA) What do you suppose it was?
SHOULDERED) A non-immediate priority. (STOPPING; RELAXING
Here we are. The TARDIS. (BEAT; REALISATION) Oh, no!
Yes — no sign of the Doctor, or Tegan. (STEPPING FORWARD) Still, at least they left us our shoes. —
That’s not it, Turlough. Look at the TARDIS!
Moss. It’s covered in moss!
Interesting. It looks like it’s trying to find a way in.
(SLIPPING ON SHOES) Yes, fascinating. But how are we supposed to open the doors without becoming infected?
Right now, I have absolutely no idea. Pass me my shoes, would you?
HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 31
SCENE 14: EXT. TOP OF CITADEL WALL
(FX: QUICK FADE UP. THRUMMING SONTARAN GRAVITY SPHERE COMES INTO LAND, HOVERS FOR A SECOND — THEN THUDS HEAVILY DOWN TO GROUND. BEAT)
(FX: FROM INSIDE) Landfall achieved, Field-Major, sir!
(FX: FROM INSIDE) More of a falling than a landing, it seems to us.

THURR: Troopers — take a humanoid each.

WITCH GUARD: The speech-less sapper...

WITCH GUARD: The bureaucratic Sergeant, who did all his fighting in Logistics...
WITCH GUARD: The cowardly greenhorn...

TURLOUGH: If the cap fits...

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 73: INT. BRIDGE OF SONTARAN BATTLESPHERE
STABB: Bring him through, Adjutant!
DOCTOR: (USHERED ONTO BRIDGE) Ah, yes. The heart of a Sontaran battle- sphere, I’ve never been so privileged. You must be — Fleet Marshal Stabb, is that right?
STABB: Stabb the Unvanquished!
DOCTOR: And a substantial crew, I see.
STABB: My clones. The cream of the Sontaran Academy!
DOCTOR: Remarkable. Now — firstly, let me just say I’m terribly grateful that you rescued me from the Rutans. For a moment there, it looked rather like my number was well and truly up.
STABB: You have been rescued from nothing, Doctor. Your death is no less certain than it was. But it will be more... protracted. (TO SONTARAN CREW AROUND) Eh, my troopers?
STABB: 20 x SONTARANS:
DOCTOR: Your species is still sore about that Gallifrey business, then. Only to be expected, I suppose. Never mind. Very well — (LOUDLY, PROCLAIMING) I offer you my complete capitulation.
STABB: Eh? Speak up, damn you!
DOCTOR: (LOUDER) Furthermore, I offer you my willing participation in any propaganda materials you may wish to create: ‘I, the legendary Doctor, hail the mighty Sontaran Empire, that has finally conquered me’ — that sort of thing.
STABB: Is this a Time Lord trick?
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 114
DOCTOR: All I ask is: first, that you rescue my friends from the surface of Samur; second, that you make every reasonable effort to reverse the damage done to them by Sontaran bacteriological weapons...
STABB: It is a Time Lord trick!
DOCTOR: . and third, that you despatch them to a neutral planet at an appropriately advanced level of development.
STABB: That is all?
DOCTOR: I don’t believe it’s asking so very much, in the circumstances.
STABB: This offer cannot be accepted!
DOCTOR: Disappointing. It was my only card, rather. Is there any particular reason why not?
STABB: Because first: if we are to make a propaganda film of you begging for mercy, we shall obtain it by submitting you to every one of the processes outlined in Field-Major Styre’s manual on humanoid resistance to torture!
DOCTOR: Styre? I didn’t realise he’d published.
STABB: Posthumously. (BEAT) Second: the moment that the Witch Guards destroy the three remaining members of the Sontaran mission to Samur, the three thousand cobalt-headed missiles carried by this battlesphere will blast the wretched planet below to less than dust!
DOCTOR: Will it now?
STABB: Making a rescue mission... impractical.
DOCTOR: Yes, I can see that. Curious, that the mighty Sontaran Empire should devote so much effort to satisfying the terms of a mystical curse. You’1ll be training up soothsayers next.
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 115
STABB: The curse of Sontar is real, Doctor! When Field-Major Thurr and his comrades succumb to the Witch Lords — then, at last, it will be lifted! And the Sontaran Empire will be able to grow more powerful than ever before! (ASIDE) Adjutant — status of Thurr’s men?
ADJUTANT: (OFF) Three life-signs still, Fleet Marshal!
STABB: Who would have thought that blundering reject would have so much fight in him?
DOCTOR: I have an idea, Fleet Marshal. While we’re waiting for Thurr and his men to succumb — why don’t you tell me more about this curse?
STABB: I have a better idea, Doctor. While we wait for Thurr and his comrades — why don’t we fight?
DOCTOR: Fight?
STABB: (ALOUD) What do you say, my warriors?
STABB: 20 x SONTARANS: (FX: STAMPING FEET) Fight! Fight! Fight! Fight! [ETC]
DOCTOR: (TO SELF) This isn’t working out quite as I’d hoped.
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 116
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 74: EXT. COURTYARD EAST
NYSSA: Tegan’s right, though. If these are not the finest sons of Sontar, how can their sacrifice lift the curse?
WITCH GUARD: There are seven great clans within the Empire.

WITCH GUARD: We shall be free of this world! We shall be free of this time!

DOCTOR: Missed again.

STABB: 20 x SONTARANS:
DOCTOR: While you catch your breath — I’m still wondering about this curse of yours, Fleet Marshal.
STABB: It was how the Witch Guard told me, when I captured the creature all those years ago.

STABB: I was a young Commander then. The conquest of Samur made me a hero. Promoted. Feted. Cloned a million times over.
DOCTOR: Only things haven’t gone so well since. For the Empire, I mean.
STABB: No. — (EFFORT) Huuurgh!
STABB: 20 x SONTARANS:
DOCTOR: That’s, what, forty pounds now?
STABB: (BREATHLESS) My club will split your skull in two, Doctor!
DOCTOR: Slow down, you’ll do yourself a damage. One last question. What happened to the Witch Guard you captured?
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 120
STABB: I took a plasma cannon to it. It evaporated into darkness, like smoke. Then it dispersed altogether.
DOCTOR: Darkness?
STABB: Eardrum trouble. I empathise.
DOCTOR: No, no. But all this is very, very interesting. I have a theory, if you’d care to hear it?
STABB: No. — (EFFORT) Huuurgh!
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 121

DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 122

WITCH GUARD: (GASPING THROUGH PAIN) The batteries in your transmitter, they cannot last!
WITCH GUARD: (DITTO) You only delay the inevitable, Tegan Jovanka!

TEGAN: Hardly. (TO WITCH GUARDS) “Get stuffed!”

DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 77: INT. BRIDGE OF SONTARAN BATTLESPHERE
STABB: (BECOMING EXHAUSTED) Stop... prancing about, Doctor!
DOCTOR: As I was saying — my theory. Suppose the decline of the Sontaran Empire didn’t in fact coincide with the placing of the Witch Guard’s curse... but the moment that you, Fleet Marshal, became a hero. Cloned a million times over, you said?
STABB: There’s barely a platoon in the Fleet that doesn’t contain a broodling descended from me!
DOCTOR: Exactly. It’s your clones, I think, that have caused those defeats. Almost as if someone, or something, had corrupted their inheritance. Made them marginally more clumsy, perhaps? A little slow, or lacking in initiative?
STABB: (EFFORT) Huuurgh!
STABB: 20 x SONTARANS:
DOCTOR: You’11l be through to the below deck if you keep on like that. (BEAT) You see, I don’t think that Witch Guard died. I think it dissipated into you.. and after corrupting your DNA, it was able to corrupt the whole of the Sontaran military machine accordingly.
STABB: Ridiculous!
DOCTOR: You realised that a while ago, of course. In your position as Fleet Marshal, only you would have been able to see the pattern develop. And if any strategists dared to notice, too — well, you could always have them melted down.
ADJUTANT: Fleet-Marshal, is this true?
STABB: Lies! All of it!
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 124
DOCTOR: Out of desperation, you decided at last to fulfil the terms of the curse. But it won’t work, Fleet Marshal.
STABB: Lies! All lies!
DOCTOR: Whatever these Witch Guards are, they’re not magical. They wanted you to send them seven of Sontar’s finest sons, for some reason. Has it not occurred to you to wonder why?
STABB: Now, Doctor. Now — I shall flatten you!!!
DOCTOR: One hundred and sixty pounds. That’s too much, even for a Sontaran. —
ADJUTANT: Fleet Marshal? Sir?
DOCTOR: I can’t claim to be the greatest authority on Sontaran physiognomy, but it looks rather like a seizure to me.
ADJUTANT: The Fleet Marshal — is dead?
DOCTOR: Still Unvanquished, I think. Do you have a medical kit, by any chance?
ADJUTANT: (CALLING OFF) Boosters! Revitalisers! NOW!
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 125
STABB: (WEAK, WHEEZY) You, Doctor. You did this... to me! I shall forma phalanx of engineers, tasked solely with devising new and exotic ways to torture you!
DOCTOR: Later, Fleet Marshal. Ah, medical kit, thank you, Adjutant. —
ADJUTANT: That — that is the air attack warning!
ADJUTANT: (FX: ‘THUNDERCRACK’ AGAINST HULL OF BATTLESPHERE. ELECTRICAL JUDDERS, AS IN SCENE 6 ETC. CONTINUE SPORADICALLY THROUGH: )
STABB: A-air attack?
DOCTOR: You destroyed two Rutan scouts, it’s no surprise to find an entire squadron not far behind. I was beginning to think they’d never arrive.
ADJUTANT: (CALLING) Battle stations, troopers! Rutan scum, incoming!
DOCTOR: (RUMMAGING THROUGH KIT) Now, what’s in this kit? .. Ah, now this is interesting. I think I’1l take it, if you don’t mind.
STABB: Doctor! You must save me!
DOCTOR: Here, Fleet Marshal — revitaliser leads. Plug yourself in — give yourself a jump start, put the grey back in your cheeks.
STABB: But — you cannot leave! (CALLING WEAKLY) Stop him, my warriors!
DOCTOR: Everyone seems rather too busy at present. Farewell, Fleet Marshal, it’s been... enlightening. (EXITS)
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 126
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 78: INT. CRASHED SHIP
THURR: (COMING TO HIS SENSES) W-where am I? Ohh — that noise, it is still in my head!
NYSSA: Back in the ship, Field-Major. I’ve reduced the transmitter’s power, so the batteries might last a little longer.
TURLOUGH: Yes, but how much longer?
NYSSA: An hour or so more, perhaps. It’s hard to tell.
TURLOUGH: A little more time to think about what it’1ll feel like to be slaughtered. That’s useful.
TEGAN: A little more time for the Doctor to get here, Turlough.
THURR: Your ‘Doctor’. Your hero of Gallifrey. Accept it — your Doctor is dead!
JORR: And we are all going to die in this dismal hole!
NYSSA: Tegan, might I have a word? In private?
TEGAN: Sure. Anything to get away from these little rays of sunshine.
VEND: Permission to ask a question, Field-Major?
THURR: Is it important, Trooper Vend?
VEND: I have been wondering. Why do we Sontarans fight?
THURR: Why? For the glory of Sontar, that is why.
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 127
VEND: Is not Sontar glorious enough already, without a billion Sontaran soldiers dying in its name each year?
JORR: Give the Trooper an acid pill, Field-Major. His mind has gone.
THURR: I agree. (PRODUCING PILL FROM BELT) Coronic acid, trooper. Place it on the tip of your tongue, so it might melt you down from the inside.
VEND: But —
JORR: Death before dishonour, Trooper! Death before dishonour!
THURR: Like Jorr says. .. That’s it, Trooper. Now swallow.
VEND: But — (SPITTING OUT PILL) — I do not want to die, sir!
THURR: Our marching anthem, Trooper. Remember it! (SINGING) Sontar! Sontar! We fight for Sontar!/The glory of Sontar is why we fight! .. (JOINED BY JORR:)
THURR: THURR & JORR: Sontar! Sontar! We die for Sontar!/The death of our enemies is why we live!
TURLOUGH: “Dulce et decorum est/pro patria mori."
JORR: This one needs an acid pill too, I believe.
TURLOUGH: It’s Latin. They had it inscribed over the roll of honour at Brendon, for old boys who'd been in the wars. It means: “How sweet and fitting it is/to die for one’s country.”
THURR: A fine sentiment!
TURLOUGH: There was more. Something about ‘Death sparing not the cowardly backs/Of battle-shy youths...’? I can’t say it ever made much sense.
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 128
THURR: But it does. It does! You see, Trooper Vend? When the time comes, we shall rush headlong towards it! To glorious oblivion!
VEND: Glorious oblivion. Yes, Field-Major.
THURR: Now — put aside your pill, and sing! Sing!
THURR: THURR, JORR & VEND: (CROONING) Sontar! Sontar! We live for Sontar!/
THURR: Sontaran troopers are bred for war! [Sontar! Sontar! We march for Sontar!/
THURR: The might of Sontar is why we march! Sontar! Sontar! We fight for Sontar!/
THURR: The glory of Sontar is why we fight! Sontar! Sontar! We die for Sontar!/
THURR: The death of our enemies is why we live!]
TEGAN: Grief, now they’re singing. That’s all we need!
NYSSA: Let them. They’re not doing any [harm-] (REELS)
TEGAN: Hey! Are you alright?
NYSSA: (SNAPS) No, Tegan, I’m not!
TEGAN: C’mon, you need to sit down.
NYSSA: (SITTING; SOFTER) This organism, in the moss. I can feel its tendrils touching my forebrain. It won’t be long now.
TEGAN: Hang on in there, Nyssa. The Doctor will sort it, you’ll see.
TEGAN: NYSSA3: But if he doesn’t...
TEGAN: He will.
NYSSA: Tegan, listen!
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 129
TEGAN: I’m listening, alright?!?
NYSSA: I need you to promise me something. In our old bedroom, in the TARDIS, there’s a small grey data recorder. If I die — listen! If I die, I need you to get the Doctor to take you back to Terminus. But you mustn’t tell him why.
TEGAN: Okay...
NYSSA: It’s complicated. He won’t find out, you see, until the future. He'll be in a farmhouse, in a blizzard, and... well, that’s not important now.
TEGAN: Finds out what? Nyssa?
NYSSA: On Terminus, they can put you in touch with a Professor Lasarti. You have to give him the data recorder. It contains everything I’ve learned about Richter’s Syndrome.
TEGAN: The virus?
NYSSA: Tell Lasarti, the password is ‘Tremas’.
TEGAN: ‘Tremas’. Got you.
NYSSA: And tell him... Tell him there was so much more I wanted to tell him.
TEGAN: (HALF-JOKING) This Lasarti. He’s not —
NYSSA: My husband. Yes.
TEGAN: Your husband?!?
NYSSA: I couldn’t tell you before, because of the Doctor. If he found out now, it’d create... complications, at a crucial point in his personal timeline.
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL) Page 130
TEGAN: Complications, you’re not wrong. You’1ll be telling me you've got kids next!
NYSSA: A boy. Well, a teenager. His name is Adric.
TEGAN: Not another one!
NYSSA: He has an older sister. Always arguing, always telling me why I’m wrong about everything, and how she knows so much better. Her name... her name is.. (DOESN’T SAY ‘TEGAN’. BUT IT’S OBVIOUS)
TEGAN: I don’t know what to say.
NYSSA: Then don’t say anything. Just promise me you’1l deliver that data recorder.
TURLOUGH: (APPROACHING FROM OFF) What are you two gossiping about? Anything important?
TEGAN: Not joining in the sing-song, Turlough? All boys together?
TURLOUGH: It seems to have fizzled out, rather. Come on, I know you’re cooking up something, huddled together like [that -]
TURLOUGH: (FX: INTERRUPTED BY COLOSSAL RUMBLING FROM THE SKY OUTSIDE: STABB’S BATTLE-SPHERE HAS JUST EXPLODED)
THURR: What is that noise?
NYSSA: It came from outside.
TEGAN: I’m gonna take a look-see. Anyone coming?
DOCTOR WHO: HEROES OF SONTAR by Alan Barnes (FINAL)
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 79: EXT. COURTYARD EAST (CONTINUOUS)
DOCTOR WHO: Page 131
DOCTOR WHO: (FX: BURNING DEBRIS RAINING DOWN FROM THE SKY. A FEW FIREBALLS
DOCTOR WHO: SWOOSH-THUD INTO THE GROUND, CLOSE BY)
TURLOUGH: (STOPPING SHORT) Fireballs?
TEGAN: Look. Up in the sky.
TURLOUGH: A big grey cloud. So?
NYSSA: Not a cloud. The aftermath of an explosion. A vapourisation, in
NYSSA: fact.

NYSSA: The Doctor detected a great mass in the sky. A vessel of some
NYSSA: kind, perhaps.

NYSSA: 4 x WITCH GUARDS (were MEZZ, CLUN, NOLD & BEKK):

TURLOUGH: This ‘battlesphere’, I take it?
WITCH GUARD: (APPROACHING) Fleet Marshal Stabb has been vanquished at last. We believe Sergeant Mezz would have been... pleased.
WITCH GUARD: Now, you can no longer hurt us. Now.

THURR: Then we embrace it. (CALLING) Troopers Jorr and Vend, fall in!

TEGAN: JORR/VEND: (STOMPING TO HALT BESIDE THURR) Field-Major./Sir!
THURR: It is our time. So — we march!
JORR: Into oblivion!
THURR: Into glorious oblivion!
WITCH GUARD: Extrude your blades, witch-kin! Let your swords drink their plasma!
THURR: Heads up, troopers! Heads up, and march! (FX: MARCHES, JOINED BY JORR & VEND) (SINGS) [Sontar! Sontar! We march for Sontar!/...
THURR: THURR, JORR & VEND [VEND FALTERING]: The might of Sontar is why we march!

TURLOUGH: No! I have to tell him! I have to make him understand!
THURR: Keep up behind there, trooper!
WITCH GUARD: Field-Major. At last.
JORR: We die now, sir?
THURR: We die — for Sontar! All our lives, we have waited for this, and now the time has [come! ]
THURR: (FX: CUT SHORT BY FURIOUS SLASHING OF WITCH GUARD BLADES. SUCKING EFFECT, AS THURR AND JORR ARE DRAINED OF LIFE)

TURLOUGH: Yes, and none too prettily. So if you don’t want to be next —
NYSSA: (FROM OFF) Turlough! Behind you!
WITCH GUARD: The coward. It is your time now.
